intro: Geissanthus scrobiculatus, commonly known as the Andean bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the high Andes of South America. It is a member of the Primulaceae family and typically grows at elevations between 3,000 and 4,500 meters. The plant features showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink, often with a distinctive throat pattern. Its leaves are usually narrow and lance-shaped, adapted to the cold, high-altitude environment. Geissanthus scrobiculatus is often found in rocky or alpine habitats, where it thrives in well-drained soils.
